clinical_study.brief_title: Short-term and Oncological Outcomes of Laparoscopic Colorectal Cancer Surgery in Obese Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Short-term and Oncological Outcomes of Laparoscopic Colorectal Cancer Surgery in Obese Patients

brief_summary.textblock: A total of 138 consecutive patients who underwent laparoscopic-assisted or open colectomy for colorectal cancer (CRC) were included in the present study. Subjects commonly shared a condition of overweight or obesity. The investigators aimed to define any difference between the two different groups (open vs laparoscopic-assisted surgery) and a series of outcomes, i.e. hospitalization, Lymph nodes number, Intra-Surgery complications, and Clavien Dindo score.

detailed_description.textblock: A total of 138 consecutive patients who underwent laparoscopic-assisted or open colectomy for colorectal cancer (CRC) were included in the present study. Intra-Surgery complications, Previous surgery, Readmission Post Intervention, Location of surgery, Duration of Surgery, Re-intervention (yes), Clearance, and CRM were collected. Subjects commonly shared overweight or obesity. The investigators aimed to define any difference between the two different groups (open vs laparoscopic-assisted surgery) and a series of outcomes, i.e. hospitalization, Lymph nodes number, Intra-Surgery complications, and Clavien Dindo score.

arm_group.description: Fifty-one (37%) out of 138 subjects underwent open-air surgery.
A total of 87 (63%) out of 138 subjects underwent laparoscopic-assisted surgery.

study_pop.textblock: 138 overweight or obese subjects. Fifty-one (37%) subjects underwent open-air surgery and 87 (63%) to VL surgery.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Body mass index >25 Kg/m2
- Colorectal cancer (CRC)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Current emergency conditions (i.e., perforation and\or occlusion)
- Pregnancy,
- Co-existing peritoneal carcinomatosis
- Contraindications to LS, such as cardiorespiratory comorbidities (CHD, CHF, and other severe CVD)
- Prior transverse resections
